games.reasoning: 1. The talent gap is overwhelming - Auburn's statistical profile (83.8 PPG, top-10 nationally in scoring) and SEC Player of the Year Johni Broome (18.6 PPG, 10.6 RPG) far outclass Alabama State's metrics (196th in scoring).

1. Louisville's defensive strength, particularly Chucky Hepburn's perimeter defense, matches up well against Creighton's ball movement-dependent offense. Creighton's vulnerability to pressure defense could be exploited. Note: Confidence reduced due to historical upset patterns in 8-9 seed matchups.

1. Michigan's significant size advantage and interior presence will be crucial against UCSD's lack of players over 6'8", likely leading to rebounding advantages and efficient scoring opportunities
2. While UCSD's turnover-forcing defense is impressive, Michigan's experience in close games (13-4 in games decided by 5 points or fewer) and stronger strength of schedule suggests they'll handle the pressure better
3. Despite the historical 12-5 upset tendency, UCSD's limited experience against high-major competition (only 3 Quad 1 games) compared to Michigan's Big Ten tournament success makes the Wolverines the more reliable pick

1. A&M's dominant offensive rebounding (#1 nationally) will be particularly crucial against Yale, likely generating 8-10 extra possessions per game. While Yale is solid on the boards, A&M's +9.3 rebound margin represents a significant advantage that should help overcome their shooting inefficiencies.

1. North Carolina's dominant First Four performance (95-68 win) demonstrates they're significantly underseeded as an #11 and playing their best basketball at the right time, with RJ Davis showing exceptional form (26 points, perfect from three).

1. Despite injury concerns, Iowa State's elite defensive metrics and proven ability to beat top teams gives them a significant advantage over Lipscomb's high-tempo offense. Their DPI rating suggests they're one of the strongest #3 seeds in recent years.

1. Marquette's exceptional lineup continuity (same starting five all season) is a significant advantage in tournament play, particularly compared to New Mexico's heavy roster turnover from last season.
2. Marquette's tournament experience (37th appearance) and recent success (Sweet 16 last year) combined with their strong performance against NCAA tournament teams (13 games) this season suggests better preparation for high-stakes matchups.
3. While New Mexico has an impressive record, Marquette's stronger competition schedule in the Big East and their ability to maintain possession (top-20 turnover margin) should give them an edge in what historical data suggests will be a close game between 7 and 10 seeds.

1. The statistical mismatch is significant - Michigan State's 6th-ranked defense and superior rebounding (8th nationally in defensive rebounding) should neutralize Bryant's primary strength of offensive rebounding.
2. While Bryant has offensive firepower (82.4 ppg), they've struggled badly against top competition, losing by large margins to KenPom top-100 teams. Michigan State's elite defense and tournament-tested coaching under Tom Izzo present an even greater challenge.
3. Historical data shows #15 seeds win only 6.9% of the time, and Bryant's profile doesn't suggest they have the exceptional characteristics of past successful #15 seeds. Their struggles against strong rebounding teams (4-8 record) is particularly concerning against MSU's physicality.

1. The significant statistical advantage for Florida (85.4 PPG vs 77.3 PPG) combined with Norfolk State's defensive efficiency issues (ranked 217th) suggests Florida's superior offense will overwhelm Norfolk State's defense.
2. While Norfolk State has shown ability to compete with major programs early in games, Florida's depth and frontline advantages should prove decisive over a full 40 minutes, particularly given Norfolk State's limited frontcourt presence.
3. Although #16 seeds have had recent success (2 wins in 6 years), Florida's strong regular season performance (30-4) and momentum from winning their conference tournament indicates they're well-positioned to avoid an upset, even with Norfolk State's efficient three-point shooting.

1. Despite the historical slight edge for #9 seeds, UConn's stronger statistical profile (particularly their elite 1.8 assist-to-turnover ratio) and predictive models favoring them with 74% win probability suggest they have a meaningful advantage.
2. While Oklahoma has shown better recent form against the spread, UConn's superior overall efficiency metrics and proven ability to perform in tournament settings (as defending champions) give them an edge in this high-stakes matchup.
3. The matchup between UConn's Liam McNeeley and Oklahoma's Jeremiah Fears appears relatively even, but UConn's overall team composition and tournament experience should help them overcome Oklahoma's recent momentum.

1. Memphis's key vulnerability matches Colorado State's strengths - the Rams' efficient offense and three-point shooting (42.8%) can exploit Memphis's defensive weaknesses, while Tyrese Hunter's injury issues further compromise Memphis's defense. Note: Confidence reduced due to historical upset patterns in 5-12 seed matchups.

1. Maryland's elite defensive efficiency (ranked 6th nationally) and balanced scoring attack with five double-digit scorers gives them multiple ways to control the game
2. The inside presence of Derik Queen (16.3 PPG, 9.0 RPG) and his recent hot streak (20.0 PPG in last five games) should be particularly effective against Grand Canyon's defense, which allows a high percentage of close two-point attempts
3. While #13 seeds have had recent success (21% historical upset rate), Maryland's statistical profile (12th in KenPom) and strong net rating (+20.7) suggest they're better positioned than typical #4 seeds to avoid an upset

1. Drake's exceptional efficiency metrics (48.1% FG percentage) and strong defensive performance (holding opponents to 58.4 points) match up well against Missouri's recent offensive struggles.
2. Drake's methodical pace and excellent ball control (1.2 assist-to-turnover ratio) should help neutralize Missouri's preferred up-tempo style, especially with Bennett Stirtz's steady floor leadership.
3. Historical trends favor the upset (39% success rate for #11 seeds), and Drake's impressive 30-3 record suggests they're particularly strong for their seed, while Missouri's recent form (losing 4 of last 5 regular season games) raises concerns.

1. Texas Tech's superior offensive efficiency (80.9 PPG, 31st nationally) and balanced scoring attack led by JT Toppin (18.1 PPG) should overwhelm UNCW's defense, especially with a fully healthy roster including Darrion Williams' return.

1. Kansas's interior defense (18th in opponent two-point FG%) matches up well against Arkansas's interior-focused offense, with Hunter Dickinson being a key defensive anchor
2. Kansas received a favorable tournament draw and is considered "arguably the most dangerous seven-seed," suggesting they're better than their seeding indicates
3. Despite Arkansas's recent momentum (5-2 in last 7), Kansas's defensive strengths and tournament experience under Bill Self give them a slight edge in what projects to be a close game

1. St. John's significant statistical advantages (30-4 record, elite defense generating 17.9 points off turnovers) combined with Rick Pitino's tournament experience create a formidable challenge for a first-time tournament team like Omaha.
2. While Omaha has strong perimeter shooting (36.7%), St. John's defensive pressure and significant talent advantage (led by Big East Player of the Year RJ Luis) should overwhelm Omaha's offense, especially given the massive gap in strength of schedule between Big East and Summit League competition.
3. The game being played in Providence gives St. John's a virtual home court advantage, and the 2025 tournament's historically large statistical gap between #2 and #15 seeds (+26.84) suggests this particular year is less conducive to major upsets in this seed matchup.

1. Duke's elite statistical profile (1st in offensive efficiency, 4th in defensive efficiency) combined with their dominant 31-3 record presents an overwhelming advantage against a Mount St. Mary's team that, while showing spirit in their First Four victory, faces significant limitations including missing key players and potential fatigue from playing their 5th game in 8 days.

1. Despite their lower seed, Baylor ranks higher in blended power ratings (25th vs 32nd) and has proven more capable against elite competition, with six wins against top-15 KenPom teams. Mississippi State is 0-8 against top-16 NET teams.

1. Liberty's superior shooting efficiency (6th in FG%, 6th in 3PT%) and strong defense (10th in points allowed) match the profile of successful #12 seed upset teams historically.
2. While Oregon has faced tougher competition, Liberty's balanced scoring attack (7 players averaging 8+ points) and elite ball security (9.4 turnovers per game) suggest they can handle Oregon's defensive pressure.
3. The historical 35.3% success rate of #12 seeds, combined with Liberty's momentum (winning CUSA championship) and strong statistical profile, make them a prime candidate for one of the typical 1-2 twelve-seed upsets per tournament.

1. Arizona's battle-tested schedule (4th toughest in country) and 10 Quad 1 victories against elite competition provide better preparation than Akron's MAC schedule
2. While Akron's 3-point shooting prowess (10.9 per game) could keep them competitive, Arizona's strong interior scoring and defensive versatility should ultimately prevail
3. The 21% historical upset rate for #13 seeds is notable, but Arizona's late-season form (Big 12 tournament runner-up) and expert consensus suggesting Final Four potential indicate they should avoid becoming an upset victim

1. BYU's elite offensive efficiency (11th nationally) and strong 3-point shooting should challenge VCU's defense, which hasn't faced many high-powered offenses this season. BYU's experience against top Big 12 competition (5-2 against teams with better defensive rankings than VCU) suggests they can handle defensive pressure. Note: Confidence reduced due to historical upset patterns in 6-11 seed matchups.

1. The significant disparity in team efficiency metrics is compelling - Wisconsin's top-15 offensive efficiency and #27 defensive efficiency gives them a clear two-way advantage over Montana's much lower rankings (#98 offense, #250 defense).

1. Saint Mary's elite defense (5th nationally, allowing just 60.7 PPG) should neutralize Vanderbilt's faster-paced offense, especially given their experience controlling game tempo (359th in pace)
2. The Gaels' significant rebounding advantage (6th nationally vs Vanderbilt's 98th) will likely limit second-chance opportunities and help control possession
3. Saint Mary's more consistent season performance (28-5 record, 85.7% win rate as favorite) compared to Vanderbilt's struggles as an underdog (35.7% win rate) suggests they're better equipped to handle tournament pressure Note: Confidence reduced due to historical upset patterns in 7-10 seed matchups.
